title: Life insurers selling 'junk' insurance via super
text:
Life insurers are routinely selling "junk" total and permanent disability products through superannuation funds, a damning review by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission has found.

ASIC singled out AMP, Asteron (formerly Suncorp Life) and Westpac, saying they had higher-then-expected declined claim rates.

The review found almost half a million people were paying for default total and permanent disability insurance through their super fund that would pay out in only the most "catastrophic" circumstances.

The cover, known as "activities of daily living" insurance, only pays out when policyholders are unable to perform activities such as feeding, dressing or washing themselves.

ASIC found 60 per cent of claims on this type of insurance product were declined.

Under MySuper rules, superannuation funds are obliged to automatically provide death and total and permanent disability insurance cover to their members, the premiums for which come out of the member's super contributions. Members are entitled to opt out but few do.
